acne.title: Acne — common care
acne.short: Acne is common; start with gentle skin care and OTC treatments.
do: Use gentle, fragrance-free cleansers twice daily
Consider OTC topical benzoyl peroxide or salicylic acid
dont: Do not pick or squeeze lesions
Avoid harsh scrubs or abrasive treatments
medicines: Prescription (see dermatologist): topical retinoids, topical antibiotics, oral antibiotics
home_remedies: Wash gently with a mild cleanser twice daily
Apply spot treatment with benzoyl peroxide (OTC) as directed
Avoid heavy makeup and oil-based moisturizers
Use cold compress for painful inflamed spots
acne.disclaimer: Informational only. Consult a healthcare professional before starting medications.

rash.title: Rash — general guidance
rash.short: Rashes have many causes; basic care soothes skin while you seek diagnosis.
do: Keep the area clean and dry
Use gentle emollients to reduce dryness
dont: Avoid unknown topical steroids without advice
Do not apply home remedies that cause irritation
medicines: Topical steroids only under physician guidance
home_remedies: Cool compresses to reduce itching and inflammation
Oatmeal baths (colloidal oatmeal) to soothe skin
Avoid known irritants (fragrances, harsh soaps) and wear loose cotton clothing
rash.disclaimer: Informational only. Seek professional care for persistent or spreading rashes.

eczema.title: Eczema — soothing and maintenance
eczema.short: Eczema benefits from moisturization and trigger avoidance.
do: Use lukewarm showers and pat dry
Identify and avoid triggers (fragrances, harsh soaps)
Use topical corticosteroids for flares under advice
dont: Avoid long hot baths that dry skin
Do not stop prescribed medication abruptly
home_remedies: Apply fragrance-free emollients immediately after bathing
Use lukewarm (not hot) showers and pat skin dry
Avoid triggers like wool or strong detergents; use gentle soaps
eczema.disclaimer: Informational only. Follow medical advice for medicated treatments.

allergy.title: Allergic reaction — what to do
allergy.short: Allergic skin reactions range from mild to severe; assess symptoms promptly.
dont: Do not apply strong topical medications without advice
medicines: Topical emollients; topical steroids under physician guidance
home_remedies: Stop using the suspected product or avoid the trigger
Cool compresses and bland emollients for irritated patches
Oral antihistamines (OTC) can reduce itching — follow package instructions
allergy.disclaimer: Informational only. Seek urgent care for breathing difficulty or swelling.

fungal.title: Fungal infection — antifungal care
fungal.short: Fungal infections respond well to antifungal treatments when used correctly.
do: Keep the area clean and dry
Use topical antifungal creams for localized infections
dont: Avoid steroid-only creams on infected areas without diagnosis
Do not share personal items like towels
home_remedies: Keep the area clean and thoroughly dry
Apply OTC antifungal cream (clotrimazole, terbinafine) as directed
Avoid tight, damp clothing; change socks and underwear daily
fungal.disclaimer: Informational only. Consult your doctor for prescription antifungals.
